previous.body:
Now I'm on to stacks. I had to rethink my strategy of going from right to left, to left to right. I was overcomplicating it.

___

# Solution
```python
class Solution:
    def evalRPN(self, tokens: List[str]) -> int:
        stack = []
        for token in tokens:
            if token in ['+', '/', '+', '-', '*']:
                right = int(stack.pop())
                left = int(stack.pop())
                match token:
                    case '+':
                        res = left + right
                    case '/':
                        res = left / right
                    case '+':
                        res = left + right
                    case '-':
                        res = left - right
                    case '*':
                        res = left * right
                stack.append(res)
            else:
                stack.append(token)
        return int(stack[-1])

            
```
O(n) = n since we iterate over all elements once. Space complexity also O(n) = n for the stack.

frontmatter.title: LeetCode 138. Copy List with Random Pointer

next.body:
This problem was tricky as I had to track Node references rather than the index given in the input.

___

# Solution
```python
from collections import defaultdict
"""
# Definition for a Node.
class Node:
    def __init__(self, x: int, next: 'Node' = None, random: 'Node' = None):
        self.val = int(x)
        self.next = next
        self.random = random
"""

class Solution:
    def copyRandomList(self, head: 'Optional[Node]') -> 'Optional[Node]':
        start = Node(head.val) if head else None
        node = start
        randoms = defaultdict(list)
        nodes = {}
        while head:
            nodes[head] = node
            node.next = Node(head.next.val) if head.next else None
            node.val = head.val
            if head.random:
                randoms[head.random].append(head)
            head = head.next
            node = node.next
        
        for val in randoms.keys():
            for neighbor in randoms[val]:
                nodes[neighbor].random = nodes[val]

        return start
```
O(n) = n since worst case is 2n due to the while loop, then at most visiting each node again when assigning the randoms' value.

post.body:
Final stack problem for this practice set is a hard question. 
Took me an hour and a half to come up with this convoluted method. Parsing numbers character by character was my first mistake.

___

# Solution
```python
class Solution:
    def calculate(self, s: str) -> int:
        parsed = []
        num = ''
        for token in s:
            if token in ['(', ')', '+', '-', ' ']:
                if num:
                    parsed.append(num)
                    num = ''
                parsed.append(token)
            else:
                num += token
        if num:
            parsed.append(num)

        s = parsed
        nums = []
        ops = []
        total = 0
        for token in s:
            match token:
                case '(':
                    ops.append('(')
                    nums.append('(')
                case ')':
                    ops.pop()
                    right = nums.pop()
                    nums.pop()
                    if ops and ops[-1] != '(' and right != '(':
                        op = ops.pop()
                        if op == '+':
                            total = nums.pop() + right
                        elif op == '-':
                            if nums and nums[-1] != '(':
                                total = nums.pop() - right
                            else:
                                total = right * -1
                        nums.append(total)
                        total = 0
                    else:
                        nums.append(right)
                case '-':
                    ops.append('-')
                case '+':
                    ops.append('+')
                case ' ':
                    pass
                case _:
                    if not ops or ops[-1] == '(':
                        total += int(token)
                    else:
                        op = ops.pop()
                        if op == '+':
                            total = int(token) + nums.pop()
                        elif op == '-':
                            if nums and nums[-1] != '(':
                                total = int(nums.pop()) - int(token)
                            else:
                                total = -1 * int(token)
                    nums.append(total)
                    total = 0
        return nums[-1]
```
O(n) = n since we iterate over all elements once. Space complexity also O(n) = n for the stack.
